items.text: I trust my gut feelings to guide me when making important decisions.
items.rationale: Reliance on intuitive, gut-level processing is a hallmark of the experiential system.

items.text: I often get a strong sense about people the moment I meet them, and I rely on that impression.
items.rationale: Rapid, holistic impressions of others reflect automatic, experiential processing.

items.text: When something feels right, I don't need to analyze it further before acting.
items.rationale: Prioritizing felt sense over deliberate analysis is central to experiential thinking.

items.text: My emotions are an important source of information when I'm trying to figure things out.
items.rationale: Using affect as information is a core feature of the experiential system in CEST.

items.text: I tend to go with my first impression rather than overthinking a situation.
items.rationale: Preference for initial, automatic appraisals over deliberation reflects experiential processing.

items.text: I can usually sense when something is wrong even before I can explain why.
items.rationale: Pre-verbal, intuitive detection of problems is characteristic of the experiential system.

items.text: Vivid images and feelings influence my choices more than cold facts do.
items.rationale: The experiential system operates through imagery, narrative, and affect rather than abstract data.

items.text: I learn best from personal experience rather than from reading instructions or manuals.
items.rationale: Learning through direct, concrete experience is a defining feature of experiential processing.

items.text: When I recall past events, I re-experience the emotions I felt at the time, and those feelings shape my current decisions.
items.rationale: Emotionally laden, associative memory retrieval driving behavior is experiential system functioning.

items.text: I find that my hunches about how things will turn out are usually accurate.
items.rationale: Confidence in intuitive predictions reflects strong engagement of the experiential system.

items.text: Stories and personal anecdotes persuade me more than statistics or data.
items.rationale: The experiential system is narrative-based and responds to concrete, emotionally engaging information.

items.text: I sometimes just know the answer to a problem without being able to explain how I arrived at it.
items.rationale: Implicit, non-verbal knowing without conscious reasoning steps is a classic experiential process.

items.text: I pay close attention to my body's signals—like tension or excitement—when weighing my options.
items.rationale: Somatic markers inform experiential processing, though attending to bodily signals could also reflect mindful self-awareness rather than purely intuitive processing.

items.text: I prefer to make decisions quickly based on how I feel rather than spending a lot of time deliberating.
items.rationale: Speed and affect-based choice are experiential, but the item could also reflect impulsivity or low need for cognition rather than a coherent experiential style.

items.text: When I face a complex problem, I like to step back and let the solution come to me rather than force it through analysis.
items.rationale: Incubation and allowing insight to emerge can reflect experiential processing, but it can also be a strategy used by highly rational thinkers who recognize the limits of conscious analysis.

items.text: I enjoy solving problems that require careful, logical analysis.
items.rationale: Enjoyment of deliberate, logical problem-solving is a core indicator of rational system engagement.

items.text: Before making a major decision, I systematically list the pros and cons.
items.rationale: Structured, deliberate evaluation of alternatives is a defining feature of rational processing.

items.text: I prefer to base my opinions on hard evidence rather than on personal feelings.
items.rationale: Valuing evidence over affect directly contrasts experiential processing and anchors rational thinking.

items.text: I am the kind of person who thinks things through very carefully before taking action.
items.rationale: Deliberate, effortful thinking prior to action is central to the rational system.

items.text: I find it satisfying to work through a complex argument step by step until I reach a conclusion.
items.rationale: Sequential, analytical reasoning and deriving satisfaction from it reflects high rational system engagement.

items.text: When someone presents me with a claim, I look for the logical reasoning and data behind it.
items.rationale: Seeking logical justification and empirical support is a hallmark of rational processing.

items.text: I tend to be skeptical of conclusions that are based on intuition alone.
items.rationale: Skepticism toward purely intuitive conclusions reflects a preference for rational verification.

items.text: I like to understand exactly why something works, not just that it works.
items.rationale: Seeking causal, mechanistic explanations reflects analytical, rational thinking.

items.text: I would describe myself as a very analytical thinker.
items.rationale: Direct self-identification as analytical maps straightforwardly onto the rational system.

items.text: When I encounter a new idea, I evaluate it by checking whether it is logically consistent.
items.rationale: Applying logical consistency checks to new information is a core rational system operation.

items.text: I believe that most problems have a correct solution if you think about them long enough.
items.rationale: Faith in the power of sustained deliberate thought to yield correct answers reflects rational system confidence.

items.text: I enjoy intellectual debates where I have to defend my position with reasoned arguments.
items.rationale: Engagement in structured argumentation and logical defense reflects rational processing preference.

items.text: I often catch myself mentally critiquing the logic of advertisements or news stories.
items.rationale: Spontaneous logical critique suggests rational processing, though it could also reflect general skepticism or cynicism rather than a broad rational thinking style.

items.text: I prefer to plan things out in detail rather than leave them to chance.
items.rationale: Detailed planning reflects deliberate, structured thinking, but could also reflect anxiety or a need for control rather than rational cognitive style per se.

items.text: I need to fully understand a situation before I feel comfortable making a judgment about it.
items.rationale: Needing full understanding before judging suggests rational deliberation, but the emphasis on feeling comfortable introduces an affective, experiential component—comfort as a signal may reflect experiential processing.
